channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Giorgia Meloni’s Hard-Right Party Leads in Italy’s Voting
item.description: Early results suggest that she could be Italy’s next prime minister, the first woman to hold the position, and the first with post-Fascist roots. It will still be weeks before a new government is formed.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: A polling station on Sunday in Rome.

item.title: Iran Protests Are Fueled in Part by Kurdish Anger
item.description: The protests that have swept Iran following the death of a woman in police custody have been especially intense in the country’s minority Kurdish population.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf and Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Protesters in Erbil, the capital of Iraq’s semiautonomous Kurdistan Region, burning an Iranian flag on Saturday.

item.title: Some Women Fear Giorgia Meloni’s Far-Right Agenda Will Set Italy Back
item.description: Some fear that the hard-right politician, whose party is expected to be the big winner in the election on Sunday, will continue policies that have kept women back.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo and Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Giorgia Meloni often talks with pride about how she started the Brothers of Italy party and rose to the top of national politics without any special treatment.

item.title: Russia Seeks to Force Ukrainians to Fight Their Countrymen
item.description: Russia is stepping up its conscription efforts even as it forces residents to vote in staged referendums that could lead to annexation, according to Ukrainian officials, witnesses and rights groups.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Remnants of St. George’s monastery in Dolyna, Ukraine, on Saturday.

item.title: Deadlier Than the Titanic: A Ferry Set Out With About 1,900 Aboard. Only 64 Survived.
item.description: Tourists, vendors, babies, hundreds of university students and a soccer team from Senegal perished in a little-known ferry disaster 20 years ago. Survivors and families of victims still want justice.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:credit: Carmen Abd Ali for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Kantene cemetery in Ziguinchor, Senegal, has 42 graves of victims of the wreck. Artists paid tribute to the deceased by painting on the walls this year.

item.title: Olaf Scholz of Germany Won’t Send Battle Tanks to Ukraine
item.description: Military assistance to Kyiv has become something of a litmus test of Olaf Scholz’s ability to lead Europe through its most significant security crisis since World War II.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany last week at the United Nations in New York. “Leadership does not mean you do what people ask you,” he said.

item.title: The New India: Expanding Influence Abroad, Straining Democracy at Home
item.description: As India rises, Prime Minister Narendra Modi has faced little pushback as he weaponizes institutions to consolidate power and entrench his Hindu nationalist vision.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia meeting in Uzbekistan this month.

item.title: North Korea Launches Ballistic Missile Off Its East Coast
item.description: The exercise was Pyongyang’s first ballistic missile test in nearly four months and came days after the U.S.S. Ronald Reagan arrived in a South Korean port.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: The United States aircraft carrier Ronald Reagan arriving in port in Busan, South Korea, on Friday, ahead of the two countries’ joint military drills.

item.title: Super Typhoon Noru Heads for Philippines After ‘Explosive’ Surge
item.description: Forecasters warned of heavy rains and winds that could bring flooding and landslides to densely populated areas of the country.
item.dc:creator: Jason Gutierrez
item.media:credit: Kevin Tristan Espiritu/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Emergency crews preparing boats and other gear on Sunday in Quezon City, the Philippines, ahead of a storm’s landfall.

item.title: Why Iranians Are Protesting Once Again
item.description: Amid growing repression, a sickly economy and bleak prospects, the death of one young woman was all it took.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Demonstrators on the streets of Tehran this past week. Protests spurred by a woman’s death in custody have expanded to include outrage over economic problems and frustration with moral strictures.

item.title: The Fight Between Armenia and Azerbaijan, Explained
item.description: The hostilities that flared again last week reflect decades of animosity over a mountain region, but the consequences could be far wider. Here’s a guide.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: A firefighter among the ruins of a house destroyed by shelling in Sotk, Armenia, last week.

item.title: Why Japan Is Angry About a State Funeral for Shinzo Abe
item.description: The fallout from Shinzo Abe’s death has taken a number of unexpected turns, casting a critical light on both his long-governing party and a fringe religious group.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Ben Dooley
item.media:credit: Noriko Hayashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A protest against the planned state funeral for Shinzo Abe, Japan’s former prime minister, in Tokyo on Monday. Many are voicing their critique of his actions in life by opposing the effort to honor him in death.

item.title: In Ukraine’s South, Fierce Fighting and Deadly Costs
item.description: The offensive in the south was the most highly anticipated military action of the summer. Ukraine is making gains, but the fighting is grinding, grueling and steep in casualties.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers at an entrenched position this month near the Kherson front.

item.title: On a Corpse’s Wrist, an Emblem of Ukrainian Fortitude
item.description: When they pulled Serhiy Sova’s body from a grave in Izium, his wrist bore a bracelet in Ukraine’s colors, given to him by his children. The image has transfixed the nation.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Anna Lukinova
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Investigators exhumed bodies at the site of a mass grave in Izium this month.

item.title: To Defend Democracy, Is Brazil’s Top Court Going Too Far?
item.description: Brazil’s Supreme Court has acted as the primary check on President Jair Bolsonaro’s power. Now many are worried the court is posing its own threat.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and André Spigariol

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Elections in Italy.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe and Amelia Nierenberg

item.title: Russia Begins Mobilizing Ukrainians to Fight Against Their Own Country
item.description: Panic and fear flooded the occupied territories as Russian forces rounded up men to fight and forced residents to vote in a staged referendum on joining Russia, Ukrainian officials and rights groups said.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: A polling station in Mariupol, Ukraine, on Saturday, the second day of a referendum on joining the self-proclaimed Donetsk People's Republic to Russia.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Protests Grow in Iran
item.description: Plus anger builds in Japan over Shinzo Abe’s state funeral and Russia tries to conscript Ukrainians.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Protesters in the streets of Tehran on Wednesday. The protests have grown to encapsulate a wide range of grievances against the government.

item.title: Roger Waters Concert in Poland Called Off After Ukraine Views Prompt Anger
item.description: In online exchanges with Ukraines first lady, the Pink Floyd co-founder said Ukraine should seek peace with Russia and blamed the United States for encouraging the conflict.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Roger Waters performing at Madison Square Garden in August.

item.title: Giorgia Meloni’s Adoption Views Worry Gay Parents in Italy
item.description: In her election campaign, Giorgia Meloni pledged to oppose surrogacy and adoption by gay couples.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:description: A campaign poster of Giorgia Meloni. She has pledged to oppose surrogacy and adoption by gay couples but said she would not touch existing civil rights.

item.title: Soviet Monuments Become Latest Target of Backlash Against War in Ukraine
item.description: Across Eastern and Central Europe, statues honoring Soviet troops for their role in defeating the Nazis in World War II have in recent weeks come down or been slated for demolition.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Katrina Kepule for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Juris Vidins, right, in front of a Red Army soldier statue in the town of Rezekne, Latvia.

item.title: Ukraine Warns of Growing Attacks by Drones Iran Has Supplied to Russia
item.description: As Moscow finds itself isolated internationally, and as its arsenal has been depleted in Ukraine, it has turned for military support to countries including Iran.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: An unmanned aerial vehicle seen on Friday over the southern port city of Odesa, where Ukrainian officials say Russia has repeatedly deployed Iranian-made drones.

item.title: In Italy’s Election, Politicians Use TikTok to Seek Votes
item.description: Lawmakers set up TikTok accounts to try to reach undecided voters before Sunday’s elections. Hilarity ensued.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:description: Silvio Berlusconi’s TikTok profile is brimming with jokes, clips from TV appearances and videos shot in a studio.

item.title: The Morning: The back story of the migrant buses
item.description: Republican governors’ immigration stunts are actually helping some migrants.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Oliver Contreras for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lever Alejos, 29, from Venezuela, is one of the thousands of migrants who arrived on buses sent by the governors of Texas and Arizona last month near Capitol Hill.

item.title: Giorgia Meloni Wins Voting in Italy, in Breakthrough for Europe’s Hard Right
item.description: Her nationalist party was the top vote-getter, leaving Ms. Meloni poised to be Italy’s first female prime minister and the first with post-Fascist roots.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Giorgia Meloni at a press conference she gave after early projections had her coalition winning a majority in Parliament, in Rome early Monday.

item.title: Exploring ‘The Land of Morning Calm’
item.description: A traveler gets beyond Seoul’s sprawl to explore tranquil thatched mountain hamlets, peaceful Buddhist temples and unhurried ‘slow food’ towns in rural South Korea.
item.dc:creator: Adam H. Graham
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Visitors explore the pine forest at Andong Hahoe Hanok Village, a UNESCO World Heritage site.

item.title: Zelensky calls on Russians to resist Putin’s conscription.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: Police officers detaining people protesting the military mobilization near Red Square in Moscow on Saturday.

item.title: The U.S. says Russia isn’t preparing to use nuclear weapons, yet.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt and Jim Tankersley
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in the city of Veliky Novgorod on Wednesday.

item.title: In a U.N. speech, Russia’s foreign minister says ‘the future of the world order’ is at stake.
item.dc:creator: Juston Jones and Hannah Wulkan
item.media:description: Sergey V. Lavrov, Russia’s foreign minister, addressing the United Nations General Assembly in New York on Saturday.

item.title: Ukraine Fights to Reclaim Territory as Russia Holds Annexation Referendums
item.description: Ukraine’s president has urged citizens to resist the Russians in occupied territories, where voting is underway in what Western officials have called “sham” referendums on joining Russia.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Valerie Hopkins and Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers in an armored vehicle in Izium on Saturday.

item.title: Protests in Russia Against Putin’s Mobilization Policy Continue
item.description: Demonstrations against President Vladimir V. Putin’s “partial mobilization” policy continued, despite the Kremlin’s crackdown on dissent.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: Russian security forces arrested hundreds of demonstrators in St. Petersburg and across Russia on Saturday during protests against the mobilization of 300,000 people announced by President Vladimir V. Putin this week.

item.title: E.P.A. Will Make Racial Equality a Bigger Factor in Environmental Rules
item.description: The agency is creating an office of environmental justice to address the disproportionate harm that climate change has caused in low-income areas and communities of color.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport
item.media:description: “Regulations in the past may not have been as protective of some communities,” said Michael S. Regan, the E.P.A. head.

item.title: Russia’s Defense Ministry shakes up its leadership.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: Colonel-General Mikhail Y. Mizintsev was announced as Russia’s new deputy defense minister on Saturday.

item.title: ‘Somebody Planted the Guns’: In Canada, a Raided, Distrusting Village Blames the Police
item.description: When a cache of weapons was found in a tiny Canadian village that has become a symbol of the far right, it didn’t take long for new conspiracy theories to start circulating.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Amber Bracken for The New York Times
item.media:description: The village of Coutts, Alberta, on the border with Montana, was the site of a large weapons seizure and of antigovernment protests this winter.

item.title: Russia’s draft is drawing criticism from far-flung regions and even pro-war hawks.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski

item.title: Putin is tightening his grip on the reins of the war as Russian losses mount.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers operate a drone near Kherson, in southern Ukraine. It was the first major city to fall to the Russians in the initial invasion, and remains the only regional capital under Moscow’s control.

item.title: How to Slow Down
item.description: In an age of instant everything, drawing invites us to slow down and appreciate the world around us.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: A Year When Everything Is Going Right for Western Canada’s Farmers
item.description: This year’s harvest will be bountiful, with prices more than offsetting increased costs for items like fuel.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Canada’s farmers are expected to harvest near-record yields this year.

item.title: Italy May Get a Leader With Post-Fascist Roots
item.description: With the hard-right candidate Giorgia Meloni ahead before Sunday’s election, Italy could get its first leader whose party traces its roots to the wreckage of Fascism.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: Supporters of Giorgia Meloni at a joint rally on Thursday for the Brothers of Italy, League and Forza Italia parties in Rome.

item.title: Iran Protests Surge to Dozens of Cities
item.description: Iranians fed up with oppressive rules and a battered economy have faced bullets, tear gas and arrests to demand an end to the Islamic Republic’s rule.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Demonstrators on the streets of Tehran this past week. Protests spurred by a woman’s death in custody have expanded to include outrage over economic problems and frustration with moral strictures.

item.title: Defying Travel Warnings, Hasidic Jewish Pilgrims Flock to Ukraine.
item.description: Tens of thousands of Hasidic Jews traditionally travel to Uman to mark Rosh Hashana with a visit to the burial site of a revered 18th-century rabbi.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner

item.title: Zelensky tells Ukrainians living under occupation to avoid conscription ‘by any means.’
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim and Maria Varenikova
item.media:description: Cheering at passing military vehicles on Friday in Chuhuiv, in the Kharkiv region of Ukraine.

item.title: More Than 700 Children Have Died in a Measles Outbreak in Zimbabwe
item.description: It is driven by a decline in child immunization during the pandemic and the influence of an anti-vaccination evangelical church.
item.dc:creator: Tendai Marima and Stephanie Nolen
item.media:description: A mother and baby waiting for measles vaccination at a clinic in Harare, Zimbabwe.

item.title: Vladimir Putin Gets More Involved in Ukraine War Strategy
item.description: The Russian president has rejected requests from commanders in the field that they be allowed to retreat from Kherson, a vital city in Ukraine’s south.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers operate a drone near Kherson, in southern Ukraine. It was the first major city to fall to the Russians in the initial invasion, and remains the only regional capital under Moscow’s control.

item.title: Russia Begins Staged Referendums In Occupied Areas of Ukraine
item.description: Under coercive conditions, with most residents gone and war still raging, Russia is putting on what it calls referendums on annexation but Ukraine and its allies call an illegal farce.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Voters on Friday at a mobile polling station during the referendum on joining Russia, in Luhansk, Ukraine.

item.title: On a corpse’s wrist, an emblem of Ukrainian fortitude.
item.description: When they pulled Serhiy Sova’s body from a grave in Izium, his wrist bore a bracelet in Ukraine’s colors, given to him by his children. The image has transfixed the nation.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Anna Lukinova
item.media:description: Serhiy Sova, whose body was exhumed in Izium earlier this month, in 2019. He was a trainer and breeder of dogs.

item.title: Putin’s Draft Draws Resistance in Russia’s Far-Flung Regions
item.description: Villagers, activists and some elected officials asked why the conscription drive seemed to be hitting poor, remote areas hardest, while pro-war hawks criticized it as chaotic.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski

item.title: Hilary Mantel Stared Down Her Past, and the World’s, With Steely Resolve
item.description: Hilary Mantel brought great precision to her writing, and asked the same of us in our reading.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Lyall
item.media:description: Hilary Mantel “was unsentimental, forthright, unafraid of stating her sometimes fierce views.”

item.title: Group of 7 countries condemn ‘sham’ referendums in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley
item.media:description: Construction workers lineup to cast ballots at a mobile polling station in Russian-controlled Mariupol in eastern Ukraine on Friday. The referendum has been called a sham by the G7.

item.title: Russian aviation scientist dies, adding to a series of suspicious deaths.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko

item.title: Church of England Stops Desmond Tutu’s Daughter From Officiating Funeral
item.description: Rev. Mpho Tutu van Furth, an Episcopal priest who is married to a woman, said the funeral of her godfather was moved to his garden to allow her to participate.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:credit: Lerato Maduna/Foto24/Gallo Images, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Rev. Mpho Tutu van Furth, right, with her wife, Marceline Tutu van Furth, in Cape Town in 2016.

item.title: Referendums in Russian-occupied Ukraine evoke fear, anger and defiance.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky, Cora Engelbrecht and Maria Varenikova
item.media:description: Residents of Luhansk, Ukraine, voted in a referendum organized by Russian authorities on Friday. Polling stations were installed across Russian-occupied Ukrainian territory for referendums on annexation by Russia.

item.title: Is Little Amal Getting Lost in New York?
item.description: The hottest celebrity in town right now is an enchanting 12-foot-tall Syrian refugee puppet. She’s drawing masses of admirers, but that’s not always a good thing.
item.dc:creator: Laura Collins-Hughes and Amir Hamja
item.media:credit: Amir Hamja for The New York Times
item.media:description: Little Amal walking along Central Park West in Manhattan.

item.title: Dozens of Migrants Feared Dead After Boat Capsizes Off Syria
item.description: Witnesses said that bodies could be seen from shore drifting in the waters just outside the port of Tartus. The Lebanese authorities said at least 75 people died, with 20 rescued.
item.dc:creator: Hwaida Saad and Cora Engelbrecht
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: Lebanese Red Cross ambulances carried bodies after a boat carrying migrants from Lebanon capsized in Syrian waters.

item.title: Berlusconi Draws Backlash for Saying Putin Was ‘Pushed’ to Invade Ukraine
item.description: Italy’s former prime minister said that the Russian president was “pushed” to invade Ukraine, remarks that drew fierce criticism days before an election.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:description: Italy’s former prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi, said President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia was “pushed” to invade Ukraine.

item.title: Abel Selaocoe Finds a Home in Improvisation
item.description: The classically trained South African cellist draws on musical traditions from across the globe for his debut album, “Where is Home (Hae Ke Kae).”
item.dc:creator: Hugh Morris
item.media:credit: Adama Jalloh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Abel Selaocoe, a classically trained South African artist, is best known for his work on the cello, but is also a singer and improviser. His mixed-genre, groove-orientated approach has won him growing influence in the classical music community.

item.title: What You Need to Know About Italy’s Elections
item.description: The elections could produce the first government led by a woman and by a hard-right party with post-Fascist roots.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz, Gaia Pianigiani and Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Italy’s national elections on Sunday come after the national unity government of Prime Minister Mario Draghi collapsed in July amid a revolt in his coalition.

item.title: The referendums are taking place in areas from which large numbers of people have fled.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: A woman cast her ballot at a polling station in the village of Krasny Yar, Luhansk region, Ukraine, on Friday.
